article.headline: Syracuse 65, West Virginia 52
article.story: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. (AP) -- Hakim Warrick moved Syracuse closer to a first-round bye in the Big East tournament. Warrick had 25 points and 10 rebounds to lead the 24th-ranked Orangemen to a 65-52 victory over West Virginia on Tuesday night. Syracuse (20-6, 10-5 Big East) can clinch a first-round bye in next week's conference tournament with a win at home Sunday over No. 7 Connecticut, or a loss by Seton Hall at Rutgers. No. 12 Providence, Connecticut and No. 6 Pittsburgh have already clinched byes. "We want that bye," said Syracuse's Gerry McNamara, who added 14 points. "We don't want to go out and have to play every day. We're going to have to protect our home court and make sure we get one against UConn." Syracuse, coming off an overtime win Sunday that ended Pittsburgh's 40-game home winning streak, didn't look spectacular against a ninth-place opponent. The Orangemen needed a late flurry of Warrick dunks to put away the Mountaineers. "A win here was important," said Warrick, who earned his 12th double-double of the season. "We didn't want to lose our momentum coming from the Pitt win. We need every win from here on out if we want that bye." Defending national champion Syracuse, in the Top 25 for the first time in a month, also improved its chances for a sixth trip in seven years to the NCAA tournament. The Orangemen have won six of seven games and have held four straight opponents to under 60 points. D'or Fischer scored a season-high 19 points and Tyrone Sally had 12 for West Virginia (14-12, 6-9), which has lost four straight. Syracuse coach Jim Boeheim now has 26 20-win seasons, the most among active coaches. Texas Tech's Bob Knight and Arizona's Lute Olson can match him this season. "I thought this would be a difficult game, and it was," Boeheim said. The Mountaineers came from 11 points down to pull within 57-52 on Joe Herber's 3-pointer with 2:47 left. But West Virginia didn't score again and its defense collapsed down the stretch. Josh Pace, who had 13 points, made a free throw, McNamara fed Warrick for a pair of lob dunks, and Warrick finished the scoring with a dunk and free throw with 47 seconds left. West Virginia has lost five straight to Syracuse, and 10 straight to ranked opponents. "We're lacking some I.Q.," said West Virginia's Kevin Pittsnogle. "We weren't too smart at the end. We need to find our chemistry again and get our heads together." West Virginia, not known for its outside accuracy, had trouble penetrating Syracuse's 2-3 zone defense in the first half. Fourteen of the Mountaineers' first 18 shots were 3-point attempts, and they made just three. Syracuse changed defenses in the second half and West Virginia went to Fischer, who scored 13 points after halftime. But his teammates managed just 10 points combined in the second half. West Virginia shot just 37 percent from the field. "We went back to the man defense and I thought we played well for a long time," Boeheim said. "Our defense has been the difference, as it has been in our last four games."
